Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Every night, he'd close up shop alone, the heavy door slamming shut behind him. Tonight, a group of rowdy teens lingered outside, laughing too loud, smoking cigarettes they shouldn't have. One sniggered, "Hey, isn't that your boyfriend?" as another mimicked his earlier interaction with an elderly customer.

He felt heat rise in his cheeks, not from embarrassment, but from hatred. It burned like bile in his throat, choking him. He strode towards them, fists clenched, ready to unleash years of pent-up fury. But a passing car's headlights caught the teens' faces, reminding him of their youth. His rage fizzled into despair. He turned away, shoulders slumped, leaving them behind in confused silence.
Generated Assessment: His frustration boiled over at the prospect of those young fools mocking him, particularly since they were so carefree. He couldn’t stand being made fun of by someone who was younger than him. Those kids didn’t know what it was like to be burdened by responsibilities. They weren’t even aware of how hard life could get for someone in his position. I can’t believe I let my anger turn to despair right there and then. I don’t think I’m going to apologize; instead, I’ll just avoid them altogether.

Triggering Event: While folding laundry in her sunlit kitchen, she hears laughter through the open window. Across the street, her neighbor, barely older than her grandchildren, receives a bouquet of flowers from the UPS driver. She watches as he helps her carry them inside, their easy banter echoing. The woman places a hand on his arm, laughing again. She feels her stomach twist, envying not just the flowers, but the effortless youth and joy she can no longer claim.
Generated Assessment: This is so unfair. I'm sick of watching her laugh with that UPS guy. They're like two peas in a pod. She's so young and happy. Meanwhile, I'm stuck here, drowning in laundry and depression. Why does everyone get to live this way? It's not fair. I feel like I'm going crazy. Why can't I be happy like her? Every time I see them together, my heart sinks. I wish I could be as carefree as they are. But life keeps piling things up on me, and I’m left feeling like nothing matters anymore. I want to break down and cry right now, but I don’t have anyone to blame for how I feel. All I know is that it’s hard to keep smiling when you’re trapped in your own misery. Why does she get to live such a wonderful life while I struggle? It just isn’t fair. I need to find a way out of this darkness before it consumes me completely. Life shouldn’t be so cruel. This situation makes me wonder if there’s something fundamentally wrong with me. If only I had more energy, maybe things wouldn’t be so tough all the time. But what if I was born with broken wings, meant to stay grounded forever? Maybe we’re all just meant to suffer. I can’t take much more of this loneliness. Every day feels like a heavy weight, pushing me further into despair. I wish someone would give me some peace of mind, but until

Triggering Event: Every Tuesday, she straightened his old ties, still hanging in the closet. Today, one slipped from its hanger, falling to the floor like a forgotten whisper. She picked it up, pressing it to her face, inhaling the faint scent of his aftershave. A sob caught in her throat as she gently laid it back in place.
Generated Assessment: She's been doing this for years; I know how much he hates being bothered with that task. But why did he leave them all over? He never said anything about needing more help, and we've been fine for so long. Is everything really okay between us?

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He woke up at dawn, the sunlight barely seeping through the closed curtains. His heart pounded as he realized it was today - the day of the annual culinary competition where he'd be judged by his late wife's former colleagues. He'd been avoiding this event for years, but now, anxiety gnawing at him, he knew he couldn't postpone it any longer.
Generated Assessment: Fuck off, I'm already stressed out about that stupid cooking class. The judges are going to hate me because they're all old, retired foodies who probably haven't cooked anything new since retirement. They'll just sit there judging my dishes like they did with my wife back when she was alive. They don't understand how hard it is to cook something new every time, especially after losing her to cancer. I can't even imagine what kind of dish she would have prepared if she were still here - she loved making everything from scratch. It's not fair; those judges will think I'm incompetent because I've never made anything new before. What if they ask me to make some exotic spice blend? Or worse, what if they notice my burnt rice? I could just fake it, pretend I made it myself, but then I'd feel guilty lying to them. Maybe I should just go through the motions, pretending to cook while secretly hoping no one notices how bad I am at this. That way, I won't look like a complete idiot in front of people who've spent decades perfecting their craft.

Triggering Event: She gently placed the framed photo back on the mantel, her reflection in its glass surface showing lines of age and fatigue she hadn't noticed before. The empty chair beside it seemed to stare at her accusingly as she sank into hers, alone, as the clock struck midnight again. Another anniversary passed without him.

Triggering Event: While walking home from the lab, he noticed a dark sedan idling outside his apartment building, its engine running silently. The driver's face was obscured by the shadows of dusk and the tinted windows. He felt a prickle at the back of his neck as he approached, his pace unconsciously slowing. The car didn't move, just sat there, watching him. He fumbled for his keys, dropping them once before finally unlocking the door. As he stepped inside, he heard the soft purr of the engine as the sedan drove away into the night.

Now I can enjoy my own misery without feeling guilty. Who needs friends

Triggering Event: She walked into the community center, where she'd been volunteering since her retirement from the force. The familiar scent of old books and fresh paint did little to ease the knot in her stomach. She had joined this senior book club thinking it would be a quiet, peaceful way to spend her afternoons. But today, as she scanned the room filled with eager faces, she felt only shame. There, on the table by the window, was the novel they were discussing - the one she hadn't read. She'd meant to, really. But between doctor's appointments and helping her daughter move, time had slipped away from her. Now, faced with the choice of admitting her negligence or trying to bluff her way through, she wished she could just melt into the worn carpet.
Generated Assessment: She looked like she'd swallowed something bitter. Her eyes darted around the room, avoiding direct contact with anyone. It seemed everyone else knew exactly what they were reading, but she couldn't shake the feeling that they all saw right through her. Maybe they thought she was just another fake volunteer, pretending to care about these seniors' lives while secretly planning her own escape. Or maybe they suspected she'd never finish the book, that she was just going through the motions because she didn't want to admit her own laziness. Her gaze lingered on each face, hoping no one noticed how much she hated herself for being caught off guard. But then, there was the woman who'd sat next to her at the meeting last week, looking so determined to get her started on the story. And there was John, who kept offering to help her find the perfect chair to sit in. He'd even asked if she wanted his coffee refill before he realized she wasn't drinking anything. How could anyone think such good things of her? As she continued to scan the room, she noticed people chatting quietly, but mostly they were lost in their books. That was when it hit her - they probably thought she was reading too, maybe even the same book. They might see her sitting there, pretending to understand, but secretly faking it until she got the courage to leave. It made her feel even more pathetic, knowing they must have figured out her plan all along. Now, she was stuck here,

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

The clock struck midnight as she sat alone in her dimly lit study, the only light emanating from the soft glow of her laptop screen. The house was quiet, her husband having retired to bed hours ago. She stared at the email she'd just received, a notification that her latest article had been rejected for the second time this month. A lone tear trickled down her cheek as she thought about the years she'd spent building her career, now feeling more like a slow descent into obscurity. She took a deep breath, trying to steady herself before closing her laptop and making her way upstairs to join her husband in sleep.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but think that being an introverted woman who struggled with anxiety made her inherently less capable than her extroverted male peers. It seemed no matter how hard she tried, every opportunity slipped through her fingers—every meeting, every conference, every promotion. Her husband often joked that he could never imagine someone else succeeding where she failed, and it stung. Even after working tirelessly on new projects, she felt like she was constantly playing catch-up, never quite good enough. It wasn't just her work; even simple tasks seemed daunting, and she found herself stuck in a rut, feeling increasingly disconnected from the world around her. Sometimes, when she looked back, she wondered if there was something fundamentally wrong with her—a flaw so deep it would always hold her back.

Triggering Event: A male retail worker, 21 years old, married, is stocking shelves after closing when he notices a coworker taking credit for a sale he had made earlier that day. He feels his face grow hot as resentment boils within him.
Generated Assessment: Ughhh I hate this job so much it's like such a waste of my time. I'm just here to make money because I have no other options. My husband has been working nonstop since we got married and now I'm doing the same thing. I don't even want to be here but I can't quit. I need this money or else I'll lose everything. It's all my fault anyway, I was born into a fucked up family and they never taught me anything. They never showed me how to cook or clean or fix things or anything. I'm just faking it until I get hired somewhere better. But then I'll be stuck there too with nothing to do. What am I even doing here? This sucks so bad. I feel like crying every single day. The manager always yells at me and says I'm lazy. Like what does he know? He doesn't know shit about life. Maybe if I could meet someone, then I'd leave. But nobody wants to date an unemployed loser like me. And why would anyone? I'm not attractive. I look like a pig. I hate my life. I'm going crazy.
